Query: How to remove or delete single cron job using linux command?

Answers.MP Summary: daemon to execute scheduled commands (Vixie Cron)
Top-3 Similar Questions: so_33255249: How to delete a cron job with Ansible?
so_58716885: Deleting an existing job/task in Crontab
Top-3 Scripts:
so_33255249: /var/spool/cron/crontab/$USER

hosts : all
tasks :
  - name : remove ntpdate cron entry
    cron :
      name  : ntpdate
      state : absent

hosts : all
tasks :
  - name : add crontab test entry
    cron :
      name  : crontab test
      job   : echo 'Testing!' > /var/log/crontest.log
      state : present

au_146384: Deleting a file owned by root
Top-3 Scripts:
so_33255249: /var/spool/cron/crontab/$USER

crontab -l

crontab -r

crontab -e

hosts : all
tasks :
  - name : add crontab test entry
    cron :
      name  : crontab test
      job   : echo 'Testing!' > /var/log/crontest.log
      state : present

hosts : all
tasks :
  - name  : remove user's crontab
    shell : crontab -r

Answers.MP Summary: as the filename. --logdir <name> Writes each synchronization log output in a new file in the specified directory. --logexpire <hours> Removes logs older than the value specified (in hours). This command is  used  with --logdir. --logflush Clears (flushes) the log file after each write action. --logdebug Also  output  debug-level  messages  in  the log (equivalent to setting the env var QT_LOGGING_RULES="qt.*=true;*.debug=true"). ) --confdir <dirname> Uses the specified configuration directory. The ownCloud Client reads a configuration file.  You can locate this configuration file as follows: On Linux distributions: $HOME/.config/ownCloud/owncloud.cfg On Microsoft Windows systems: %APPDATA%\ownCloud\owncloud.cfg On MAC OS X systems: $HOME/Library/Preferences/ownCloud/owncloud.cfg The configuration file contains settings using the Microsoft Windows .ini file format. You can overwrite changes using the ownCloud configuration dialog. NOTE: Use caution when making changes to the ownCloud Client configuration  file.   Incorrect settings can produce unintended results. for │ │                            │         │ new server notifications │ │                            │         │ in milliseconds.         │ └────────────────────────────┴─────────┴──────────────────────────┘ ┌────────────────────────┬─────────┬──────────────────────────┐ │[General] section       │         │                          │ Top-3 Scripts:
so_24503549: for filename in `find /path/to/files -type f -mtime +10`; do echo "rm $filename"; done

for filename in `find /path/to/files -type f -mtime +10`; do rm $filename; done

for filename in `find /path/to/files -type f -mtime +10`; do echo "rm $filename"; done > myremove.sh

Answers.MP Summary: queue, examine, or delete jobs for later execution
Top-3 Similar Questions: so_69083310: Delete a newly created file using shell script after 5 minutes
Top-3 Scripts:
so_69083310: #!/usr/bin/env bash
script_path="$(realpath -s -- "$0")"
# start script
...
# end script
echo "rm -- \"$script_path\"" | at "now + 5 minutes"
